POST HOSPITAL, COLUMBIA BARRACKS, CUBA,
MAY 28, 1900.
To the
ADJUTANT,
Columbia Barracks, Cuba.
SIR:
div1.p:
I have the honor to inform you that on May 23, 1900, Packer
Henry S. King was admitted to the Detention Ward as a Yellow Fever
suspect, and on May 24th Charles E. Sherwood, 1st class Sergeant,
Signal Corps, was admitted also as a suspect.
The diagnosis in both cases was confirmed May 24th.

James W. Balantine, Private Co. “D”, 8th Infantry, was admitted
to Receiving Ward on May 24th and on May 26th developed symptoms war-
ranting removal to Detention Camp. Diagnosis confirmed same date.

The first two cases lived at No. 20 General Lee St., Quemados, Cuba
and had been under the treatment of two native physicians for two days
before suspicion was arroused.

The wife of Packer King accompanied him to the Detention Ward
where she now is.

Every precaution was taken to prevent the spread of the disease,
and other occupants of the house are under control and observation.

None of the cases have been yet traced to the source of infection
though all deligence has been observed.

All the parties seem to possess excellent characters and dis-
claim any association with persons likely to be infected, or have any
of them save Sergeant Sherwood visited the City of Havana for a long perio
“D” Company, 8th Infantry, is under observation.

Being denied a disinfecting plant I shall destroy all property
by fire deemed necessary and cover the same by certificate.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, A.N. Stark. Capt. and Asst. Surgeon, U. S. Army,
Surgeon.
&.Q.1933.
